abstract: Without people, cats, dogs and other introduced threats on some of the more distant Papua New Guinea islands, scientists get a sense of how many birds would be present if all of the islands were pristine.
snippet: Without people, cats, dogs and other introduced threats on some of the more distant Papua New Guinea islands, scientists get a sense of how many birds would be present if all of the islands were pristine.
lead_paragraph: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.
